clusters.title: News Wrap: South Korea negotiates release of workers detained in U.S. raid
clusters.neutral_headline: South Korea, U.S. Reach Deal on Detained Workers
bullet_summary: More than 300 South Korean workers detained following a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia will be released and brought home, the South Korean government announced Sunday
Presidential chief of staff Kang Hoon-sik said South Korea plans to send a charter plane to bring the workers home
Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals

items.title: News Wrap: South Korea negotiates release of workers detained in U.S. raid
items.standfirst: In our news wrap Sunday, South Korea reached a deal with the U.S. to release hundreds of South Korean workers detained in last week’s immigration raid on a Hyundai plant in Georgia, Russia launched a massive drone and missile attack on Kyiv, Japan’s Prime Minister Ishiba resigned from office, and…

items.title: South Korea reaches deal with U.S. to return home 300 workers detained in Hyundai plant raid
items.standfirst: More than 300 South Korean workers detained following a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia will be released and brought home, the South Korean government announced Sunday.
items.content: More than 300 South Korean workers detained following a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia will be released and brought home, the South Korean government announced Sunday.

items.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
items.standfirst: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. ai_summary: South Korea and the U.S. reached an agreement regarding detained South Korean workers.
Hundreds of South Korean workers were detained in a U.S. immigration raid.
The raid occurred at a Hyundai-LG electric vehicle battery plant in Georgia.
The agreement allows for the release and return of the detained workers.
The sudden detentions strained diplomatic and economic relations between the nations.

clusters.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Launches Large Drone Attack on Ukraine
bullet_summary: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said
Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles

items.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
items.standfirst: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.

items.title: Ukraine government building damaged in large Russia aerial attack

items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.

items.content: Moscow’s forces fire 805 drones in one night, striking government building in Kyiv

items.title: Russia hits Ukraine with more that 800 drones and decoy drones in biggest-ever aerial barrage
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.

items.title: Record Russian drone attack pounds Ukraine, damaging government building

items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.

items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.(Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

ai_summary: Russia launched a large aerial attack on Ukraine using drones and missiles.
The attack damaged a government building in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.
Ukraine's Air Force reported over 800 drones and decoys were used.
The attack is the largest aerial barrage since the war began.
Several people were killed across Ukraine during the attack.

clusters.title: Thousands flock to Vatican as teenager made first millennial saint
clusters.neutral_headline: Pope Declares First Millennial Saint
bullet_summary: Reported by BBC World, Guardian World, France24 and others

items.title: Thousands flock to Vatican as teenager made first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.
items.content: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.

items.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died age 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
items.standfirst: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...
items.content: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope declares 'God's influencer' first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.

items.title: Pope Leo declares teen millennial , known as ‘God’s influencer’, a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, a digital pioneer, used his computer skills to spread Catholic teaching globally.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, a digital pioneer, used his computer skills to spread Catholic teaching globally.

items.title: Pope Leo declares Italian teen computer whiz a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.

items.content: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.

items.title: A teen nicknamed 'God's influencer' has become the first millennial saint

items.content: Carlo Acutis, who died of leukemia at 15 in 2006, is known in the Catholic Church as "God's influencer" for harnessing technology to spread the word about miracles.(Image credit: Valerio Muscella for NPR)

items.title: Teen known as 'God's influencer' to become the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.
items.content: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.

ai_summary: Pope Leo XIV declared Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint.
Acutis was an Italian teenager who died at age fifteen.
He was known as "God's influencer" for spreading faith online.
Thousands attended the Vatican ceremony for the canonization.
The Pope also canonized Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic.

clusters.title: Japan's Shigeru Ishiba resigns after his party suffered a historic defeat in a summer election
clusters.neutral_headline: Japan Prime Minister Ishiba Resigns After Election Losses
bullet_summary: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election
Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday

items.title: Japan's Shigeru Ishiba resigns after his party suffered a historic defeat in a summer election
items.standfirst: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election. Story by Catherine Viette.
items.content: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election. Story by Catherine Viette.

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns after election defeats

items.content: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.

items.title: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns
items.standfirst: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.
items.content: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.

items.title: Japan PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign amid fallout from disastrous elections
items.standfirst: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...
items.content: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to resign
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.(Image credit: Philip Fong)

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to step down

items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.

items.title: Embattled Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign, media report
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. James Simms, a freelance journalist based in Tokyo reports on the political crisis.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. James Simms, a freelance journalist based in Tokyo reports on the political crisis.

items.title: Japan’s embattled Prime Minister Ishiba resigns after election debacle

items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned on Sunday following calls to take responsibility for his party's historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.

ai_summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced his resignation.
He faced pressure following a historic defeat in elections.
The ruling Liberal Democratic Party lost its majority in elections.
Ishiba had been in office for less than one year.
His resignation is expected to cause political turmoil.

said Saturday it’s no longer detecting issues with its Azure cloud platform after multiple international cables in the Red Sea were cut

items.title: Carlos Alcaraz beats rival Jannik Sinner at U.S. Open for 6th Grand Slam title

items.content: Sunday's showdown was the third Grand Slam tournament in a row where these elite, young rivals met to decide the champion.

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner to lift US Open 2025 as Trump watches on

items.content: Alcaraz returns to No.1 spot after winning his sixth Grand Slam title and second of 2025 in four sets in New York.

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner, wins US Open
items.standfirst: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz defeated Italy's Jannik Sinner in the US Open finals on Sunday, winning the tournament for the second time and becoming a six-time Grand Slam champion.Alcaraz achieved victory i...
items.content: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz defeated Italy's Jannik Sinner in the US Open finals on Sunday, winning the tournament for the second time and becoming a six-time Grand Slam champion.Alcaraz achieved victory i...

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner to win US Open title and secure world number one ranking
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4 to win his second US Open title and reclaim the world No. 1 ranking Sunday. The 22-year-old Spaniard produced a dazzling display of athleticism and shot-making to overpower Sinner in their third Grand Slam final of the season.
items.content: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4 to win his second US Open title and reclaim the world No. 1 ranking Sunday. The 22-year-old Spaniard produced a dazzling display of athleticism and shot-making to overpower Sinner in their third Grand Slam final of the season.

items.title: LIVE: Alcaraz beats Sinner 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4 – US Open final 2025
items.standfirst: Alcaraz wins his second Grand Slam of the year by beating Sinner in the US Open men's singles final in New York.
items.content: Alcaraz wins his second Grand Slam of the year by beating Sinner in the US Open men's singles final in New York.

items.title: Sabalenka retains US Open title with straight-sets win over Anisimova
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.

ai_summary: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in the US Open final.
Alcaraz won his second US Open title.
He is now a six-time Grand Slam champion.

Alcaraz regained the world number one ranking.

items.standfirst: American influencer and pilot Ethan Guo has been released to mainland Chile after being stuck at an Antarctic air base for two months. The 20-year-old was attempting to become the youngest person to fly solo to all seven continents when Chilean authorities accused him of landing illegally on their Antarctic territory.
